Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Novel Attractants to Control the Spotted Wing Fruit Fly, Drosophila suzukii
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project proposes to develop novel attractants for the spotted wing fruit fly, Drosophila suzukii. D. suzukii is an invasive insect pest endemic to South East Asia that targets a variety of economically important soft-fruit crops, thus posing a serious threat to US agriculture. The pest's range is rapidly expanding and traditional control methods, such as pesticide treatment, are problematic. An effective bait-and-kill device would offer specific advantages by avoiding the wide dispersal of broad-range insecticides and protecting the environment, beneficial species, and organic farms in the area. However, this device depends on the availability of effective attractants, the focus of this proposal. This project incorporates several novel platform technologies comprising a high throughput assay system for rapidly identifying molecules that interact with insect chemosensory proteins. These molecules have the potential to affect D. suzukii behavior, and, once identified, they will be subsequently evaluated for behavioral effects on living flies. Thus, the project will result in lead molecules for a next-generation, effective D. suzukii attractant formulation useful in trapping and population control.


The broader impact/commercial potential of this project, if successful, will be the development of a platform technology applicable to rapidly generating novel control products for insect pest species of economic, agricultural, or medicinal significance. No specific D. suzukii attractant currently exists; bait-and-kill devices for D. suzukii would allow a shift away from the widespread spraying of insecticides to a more targeted, responsible control methodology utilizing efficient bait-and-kill stations. A device utilizing an effective attractant would benefit the US agriculture industry since it would allow safe and effective D. suzukii control. Moreover, the platform technologies utilized herein have broader commercial impacts, as they are directly applicable to the control of other insect pest species.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will provide novel attractants for the agricultural pest, the spotted wing Drosophila (SWD).

SWD is a highly invasive pest species that threatens numerous fruits, such as strawberries, blueberries, raspberries, peaches, plums, nectarines, grapes, cherries, and stone fruit and thus poses significant economic risk to US agriculture. Current control strategies involve integrated pest management (IPM) and rely on judicious use of wide spectrum insecticides, trapping programs to monitor the extent of infestations, etc. Mainstream attempts to control the fly have so far been relatively conventional and thus pose problems in and of themselves: sprayed insecticides frequently result in the development of resistance among insect pest populations, can harm the environment, and are increasingly falling out of favor with the general public; insecticides can also harm beneficial species, as seen with their recent implication in honeybee colony collapse disorder.

Species-specific bait-and-kill stations can overcome the limitations of sprayed insecticides. Such stations would lure SWD specifically, and the insects would be eliminated in a controlled, contained manner that does not rely on the dispersal of insecticides. However, bait-and-kill stations as described must rely on a highly effective, species-specific attractant to act as the bait or lure for SWD. This proposal thus focused on the development of such an attractant, using a new, validated approach based on rational design that systematically isolates compounds capable of altering insect behavior by manipulating the insect chemosensory system.

To meet our goal of developing novel attractants, this project utilized our platform technologies to first characterize the chemosensory system of SWD with emphasis on the chemosensory protein (CSP) components that initiate or control key insect behaviors such as feeding or host plant location. These chemosensory proteins were subsequently expressed in vitro and targeted in a high-throughput screening assay, called Attenu, which identifies ligands for each CSP. The ligands were then evaluated for their potential behavioral effects on living flies.

A combinatorial chemical library comprising a total of 30,000 small molecules was screened using recombinant CSPs expressed in vitro in order to identify compounds from the library that bind to the CSPs. These compounds have the potential to interfere with CSP function, and thus to alter fly behavior. The lead compounds were then tested with living flies in behavioral assays including T-maze assays to determine which compounds have stimulatory (attractant) effects.  Promising leads will be further refined during Phase II to yield commercially viable novel attractant formulations for incorporation into bait-and-kill stations or traps.

The work performed has established a novel means of rapidly isolating new insect control products targeted against specific pest species. The innovations necessary to achieve the goals described here represent a paradigm shift in insect control product design, and the resulting platform technologies are applicable to the control of other pest species. 

 


Last Modified: 01/22/2014
Modified by: Daniel F Woods
